bibl.title: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to L.L. Williams, Jr., April 26, 1925

div1.p: [Carter] discusses the comparative efficacy, as a malaria vector, of three main species of Anopheles mosquitos in the United States.

div1.head: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to L.L. Williams, Jr., April 26, 1925
div1.opener:
/LC
2122 California St., N. W.,
, D. C.,
April 26, 1925.
Surgeon L. L. Williams Jr., U. S. P. H. S.
% State Board of Health,
Richmond, Va.
Dear Louis:
div1.p:
Your letter of April 7th. gave me great pleasure and I had ans-
wered it sooner but for a couple of heart attacks forbidding all writing.
This is dictated.

What you have to tell me about Virginia is surely interesting. Your
statement that quads. were mainly responsible for the malaria in Virginia
and that they were--so far as Virginia is concerned--practically a pond
production is, I am quite sure, true; and while I know and have preached
that there is considerable regional variation in the biology of Ano-
pheles in the U. S., it is also measurably true for all parts of it
that I have seen.

You will find your statements set forth or suggested in the report
Of LePrince: Griffitts and myself on the impounded water survey of 1915.
It was published in 1916. Also in a little brocheur attempting to eval-
uate the proportional efficacy of quads and puncts in nature in the U. S.
put out in the spring of 1917, beginning with the survey of the Camp
Meade district and which should have been--but was not--accompanied with
a map showing the relation between breeding places by species and mal-
aria cases.

The first little paper is really of value in what it suggested--
more it may be than in what it proved:
1/ That puncts produced earlier in the spring (first flight)
flight)
-2-
and later in the fall than quads.; the interval of time being considerable
in both cases.
2/ That these species differed also in the nature of their breeding
places: quads. practically confining themselves to ponds and large pools,
including--it may be--seepage areas also; while puncts. were essentially
stream breeders--taking also pools; cow-tracks et. al and little marshes.
3/ That during the day-light in summer weather puncts. were practi-
cally not found within occupied residences of men: stables: cow houses:
under railroad culverts and in cool places around walled-up springs: in
woods and banks of streams etc. all being preferred by them.

The deduction was drawn that unless they came into residences by night
and left them at day-light they would not be a serious vector of malaria
as compared to quads. We had planned observations to determine if this
occurred, as well as to determine if they had marked preference for the
blood of animals as compared with that of man (Roubaud and von Wesselfeld--
I think this is the name--had not then written). Leprince: Griffitts and
Hayne got considerable-- though not entirely satisfactory-- data on the
problem the next year, I being in South America. The War stopped all
research on this problem.

Dr. (Miss) Ludlow, the Entomologist for the Army Medical Museum, was
quite certain that they entered residences at night and left before full day-
light, but had no sufficient evidence therefor. There is an Indian species
that does this, however. Also they were found quite freely in residences
in the spring and late fall,
but were certainly not a domestic mosquito in the sense that quad. is.
As possibly you know, I have been pressing ever since that time:

1: To determine the comparative efficacy as vectors of malaria in na-
ture of the three main species we have in the U. S. and if for any one of
them this should be so low that it could reasonably be neglected to limit
our control measures to those of which this was not so: their breeding hab-
hab-
-3-
its being quite certainly so different that this could be done economically.

I have kept my eyes and mind open for this since that time, though only
incidental observations have been made, until, I judge, last year.

In 1915 I had a perfect place for reliable and sufficient data by the
dissection of puncts and quads. At Talladega Springs we had 100% infection
of men (history index). Both species were abundant (puncts in excess) and
I asked von Ezdorf if he could send Mitzmain up there to do this work.
This, it seems, was not practicable and his work there later was only when
malaria had enormously diminished and Anopheles of both species also.

I must confess, however, that I do not go as far as I understand Darl-
ing and yourself went at the New Orleans Conference: I say “understand” be-
cause I have received no account save a verbal report of this meeting, because
I have seen some places un which there was considerable--or even much--mal-
aria in which only punctipennis could be accused.

As a general rule, however, especially where money is scarce, I think
that punctipennis may be neglected. Whether this is as true of crucians is
rather more of a question. The sea-coast crucians, I think, have shown them-
selves fairly efficient malaria carriers. Root says, however, that it is
doubtful if they be the same species as the crucians in the higher country.
Against this latter I have no data.
I would add two other things only to this matter:

1/ In attempting to determine if puncts. feed freely on human blood
(I know the results obtained at Mound) LePrince and Hayne in 1916 found that
all of the bites they received on porches, of which they could identify the
species (110) were punctipennis. No bites received by them in the house.

Barret of Charlotte, however, a careful observer and most reliable man,
reports himself and his wife both bitten in the house--in the spring, how-
ever, by puncts. Not many times, however.

I am sending you a reprint of mine and an unfinished article that I in-
in-
-4-
tended to read in Jamaica. I send the first simply that you may under-
stand what the second means, for this latter only is concerned with Ano-
pheles. When I got into the second paper I found that I did not know e-
nough to make any wise a complete paper of it, and that even what I knew
would make--with the other--a small book rather than a paper.

I am quite sure that an investigation as to the preferential and com-
pulsory breeding places of the different species of Anopheles will well pay
us. I think, however, that this had best be done incidentally, keeping one's
eyes open while going about ordinary malaria work, for there is much to be
done and few to do it, and done incidentally this way a good deal can be
learned with no added expense. The object, of course, is to determine what
breeding we can afford to neglect, remembering that we are not trying to
eliminate even the vector species, only to control them so that there are
left none of sanitary importance.

There are four points in the Impounded Water matter I feel an ob-
ligation to take up
1: The consideration of the effects which determine the production
of malaria by impounding a large body of water:
2: The effect of filling the pond on the mosquitoes in a flooded
area:
3: What influence--if any--does the existence of a pond have on Ano-
pheles production outside of its flowage contour?
4: What deduction as to the effect of the pond production of its dis-
trict can be drawn from a comparison of the production from the same sized
area outside the pond and in the pond?

I am purposing to undertake this as soon as I finish a Section of the
Yellow Fever History on which I am working. I think I will not make an ar-
ticle of it for publication as it will require more pains and time than is
apparently available therefor, but if I do not, it will be written out in
in
-5-
several copies and one sent you: LePrince: Griffitts and Maxcy. It will
be more suggestive than determinative--I mean what I am going to write
will be--and it will be up to you fellows to work it up.
Love to Gertrude: “Louis-Lu” and yourself.
